conclusion: Problem involves two charged balls connected by a rod forming a dipole in a magnetic field.
Objective is to find minimum initial angular velocity for dipole to reverse orientation.
Two charges +q and -q with mass m connected by rod of length d in uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to XY-plane.
Dipole starts aligned with X-axis with initial angular velocity ω₀ in XY-plane.
Center of mass is at origin with initial velocity v₀ parallel to XY-plane, v₀ = 0.
Center of mass doesn't move; only rotation matters.
Dipole should be aligned in opposite direction along X-axis at some point.
Magnetic force on moving charge is given by F = qv × B.
Magnetic field B is along Z-axis.
Dipole starts aligned with X-axis and rotates in XY-plane with angular velocity ω₀.
Position vectors of charges at t=0: +q at (d/2, 0, 0), -q at (-d/2, 0, 0).
Position of +q as dipole rotates: r₊ = [(d/2) cos(ωt), (d/2) sin(ωt), 0].
Velocity of +q as dipole rotates: v₊ = [-(d/2) ω sin(ωt), (d/2) ω cos(ωt), 0].
Position of -q as dipole rotates: r₋ = [-(d/2) cos(ωt), -(d/2) sin(ωt), 0].
Velocity of -q as dipole rotates: v₋ = [(d/2) ω sin(ωt), -(d/2) ω cos(ωt), 0].
Magnetic force on +q: F₊ = q v₊ × B = q [(d/2) ω cos(ωt) * B, (d/2) ω sin(ωt) * B, 0].
Magnetic force on -q: F₋ = -q [(d/2) ω cos(ωt) * B, (d/2) ω sin(ωt) * B, 0].
Total magnetic force on dipole is F₊ + F₋ = 0.
Consider torque due to magnetic forces: τ = μ × B.
